image.altText: A dark-haired woman wearing a black jacket staring directly at the camera

props.synopsis: The ACT Greens defend their vetting process after admitting to knowing about a candidate's blog post comparing September 11 mastermind Osama bin Laden to Jesus Christ.

title.children: ACT Greens vetting process in question after candidate’s blog post about terrorist leader Bin Laden surfaced

image.altText: David McBride looks into the camera in a tight closeup portrait. He is wearing glasses and stands in a dark room.

props.synopsis: David McBride has been in jail since May this year when he was given a nearly six-year sentence for sharing secret military documents with journalists.

title.children: Former military lawyer David McBride granted leave to appeal convictions for sharing secret military documents

image.altText: Kangaroo lying down on the grass.

props.synopsis: Thousands of kangaroos are involved in accidents on Canberra's roads each year. In many cases, those behind the wheel or who stumble upon an injured animal after it's been hit don't know what to do or how to help.

title.children: ‘Don’t take matters into your own hands’: What to do if you hit a roo

image.altText: Shoppers walk through Dickson shops in ACT during winter July 2012

props.synopsis: The ACT Magistrates Court sentences Christopher Lichtwark to nine months in jail, suspended from today, with an 18-month good behaviour order.

title.children: Man who chased three teenage girls asking for sex is allowed to walk free with suspended jail sentence

image.altText: Assala Sayara speaks at Pro-Palestine rally.

props.synopsis: Protesters have gathered outside Federal Parliament to demand Australia sanction Israel for its actions in Gaza and Lebanon, a day after commemorations a year on from the Hamas terrorist attack on southern Israel.

title.children: 'We come with rage': Pro-Palestine protesters say ongoing conflict taking emotional toll on local community

image.altText: ACT Labor Leader Andrew Barr and Canberra Liberals Leader Elizabeth Lee shake hands

props.synopsis: The leaders of the ACT's two major parties have outlined their visions – and traded barbs – over the future of Canberra at the ACT leaders' debate, but key questions remain unanswered.

title.children: The only televised debate between the ACT's major party leaders left some questions unanswered

image.altText: A building sign that reads 'ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal'.

props.synopsis: In its final ruling the ACT Civil and Administrative Tribunal found overwhelming support for the conclusion pit bull cross Buddha posed a risk to the safety of the public and other animals.

title.children: 'Threat to people and other dogs': Canberra owner fails to overturn ruling her dog should be put down

image.altText: Chloe Hosking raises her fist as she rides across the line

props.synopsis: One of Australia's most successful female road cyclists, Chloe Hosking, was forced into early retirement when her cycling team collapsed just weeks out from the start of the European cycling calender.

title.children: One of Australia's most successful female road cyclists' careers was cut short — and it's not uncommon

image.altText: A sign explaining preferential voting at an ACT election polling place.

props.synopsis: From news, analysis and explainers through to election previews, key electorates and candidates, ACT Votes has the latest on the upcoming state election. Click through to read more.

title.children: ACT Votes 2024 — stay up to date with the latest election news and analysis

image.altText: A red hammer in a circle on a green background on the side of a building.

props.synopsis: Bunnings is Australia's most trusted brand. But allegations the hardware chain has been abusing its market power have prompted a Senate inquiry, that is set to scrutinise the market power of many large format retailers.

title.children: Concerns suppliers to Bunnings and PetStock won't speak to Senate inquiry for fear of losing contracts

image.altText: A sign reads 'BEAUMARIS PRIMARY SCHOOL' behind gum leaves.

props.synopsis: A survivor of "shocking" sexual abuse at a Melbourne primary school has received what his lawyer has called "the biggest publicly-known payment to an abuse survivor in Australia" in an extraordinary $8 million settlement with the Victorian Education Department.

title.children: Sexual abuse survivor to receive $8 million in record-breaking settlement

image.altText: A woman wearing a dark green hijab and blazer stands in a grass field, serious expression on her face

props.synopsis: Fatima Payman's new political party may not be troubling Labor, but it still has plenty of other headaches to worry about.

title.children: Fatima Payman's big reveal of her new political party has done little to trouble Labor

image.altText: 10 or so people searching in rubble for victims.

props.synopsis: Yoav Gallant has warned an Israeli strike on Iran in response to its recent missile attack would be "lethal" and "surprising", as a separate Israeli air strike hit a Lebanese Civil Defense centre in southern Lebanon, killing five members stationed there.

title.children: Israeli retaliation against Iran will be 'lethal, precise and surprising,' defence minister says

image.altText: A woman with long hair wears a face mask with the flag of Taiwan on it

props.synopsis: On Taiwan's national day, the disconnect between international enthusiasm for the island's independence and its domestic politics paints a complex picture of its evolving identity.

title.children: Taiwan faces an identity crisis as genuine global support falls short

image.altText: Palm trees sway as a car drives during heavy rain

props.synopsis: Milton speeds towards Florida, and despite fluctuating strength, authorities warn it will continue to grow in size and bring life-threatening storm surges.

title.children: Hurricane Milton begins to lash western Florida ahead of expected landfall in Tampa Bay

image.altText: A rickshaw in Bangladesh is cycled through flood waters covering the frame with a passenger in tow.

props.synopsis: A study of scenarios where the world temporarily exceeds 1.5C of warming raises concerns for effects that may not be reversible for decades — or longer.

title.children: Temporarily overshooting 1.5C climate target more damaging than we thought: study

image.altText: Dreyfus in profile, the reflection of parliament in glass on either side of him.

props.synopsis: Saying that he never wants a repeat of the Robodebt scandal, the attorney-general will introduce laws to oblige public servants to cooperate with investigations, and strengthen ombudsman powers.

title.children: Seeking to prevent another Robodebt scandal, new laws would force public servants to comply with investigations

image.altText: A graphic showing a hand holding a phone. It is superimposed on a drawing of Australia and surrounded by social media apps

props.synopsis: As a social media summit this week discusses the merits of Australia's proposed world-leading ban for teenagers, Ange Lavoipierre asks: why have so few others made it down this path?

title.children: No other government has enforced a total ban for teenagers on social media – so why does Australia think it can?

image.altText: A dark-haired woman stands in a unit near a window that overlooks a road.

props.synopsis: A man broke into this woman's home and raped her after she returned from a jog. She's challenging courts and prisons to do justice differently in the hope of curbing re-offending and putting survivors at the centre of the story.

title.children: Kat was violently raped by a stranger. She found justice by confronting him in jail

image.altText: Benjamin Netanyahu and Joe Biden shake hands in the Oval Office.

props.synopsis: Joe Biden and Benjamin Netanyahu have broken nearly two months of silence with a phone call at a tense time in the Middle East — and in their relationship.

title.children: After expletive-ridden extracts released, Biden and Netanyahu talk for the first time in months

image.altText: Three young women eating instant noodles with chopsticks.

props.synopsis: Munch on a packet of chips, slurp up a bowl of noodles or tuck into a salami sandwich, and there's a good chance you're also eating monosodium glutamate (MSG). So is it really as bad for us as we're led to believe?

title.children: MSG has been misunderstood for decades. Scientists are now correcting the record

image.altText: The Rio Tinto building external framed by another building and tree.

props.synopsis: Iron ore giant Rio Tinto has announced it will buy Arcadium Lithium for almost $10 billion in an all cash deal, while the Australian share market is set to follow Wall Street higher on Thursday. Follow live.

title.children: Rio Tinto snaps up Arcadium Lithium for $9.9b, ASX to follow Wall Street higher

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Federal government to introduce 'landmark' merger reform laws
Could Google be forced to break up its business?
Market power of 'big box' retailers to be scrutinised by Senate inquiry

image.altText: Olivia Kernick dives in for a try for Australia Jillaroos during a World Cup game.

props.synopsis: The Sydney Roosters were having a glorious time celebrating their NRLW premiership, until the Jillaroos squad was announced and Olivia Kernick found out she had been dumped.

title.children: Investigation reportedly launched into Jillaroos axing as Dally M winner opens up on 'bittersweet' moment

image.altText: Jake Stringer walks from the field after the Bombers' AFL loss to the Crows.

props.synopsis: Jake Stringer is interested in a move interstate to continue his career, but the Giants are yet to place an offer to Essendon. Follow live as we bring you all the action from day four of the AFL trade period.

title.children: Giants weighing up Jake Stringer trade as clubs butt heads amid tense negotiations

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Carlton 'all but ruled out' of Dan Houston race
Giants forward re-signs amid Bombers links

image.altText: A boy stands in a doorway while a police car with flashing lights is parked outside.

props.synopsis: Claire thought that she'd escaped domestic violence after leaving her abusive partner, but she then struggled to find help with the violent meltdowns from her trauma-affected son.

title.children: Claire's son had violent meltdowns so bad she called the police. Here's what she wished she knew then

image.altText: Aerial view of man working on laptop at an airport.

props.synopsis: Avoiding opening your devices with your face is one data-safe travel tip shared by a cyber security expert in the wake of a worrying breach of travellers' passport information at an Indonesian airport.

title.children: Tips on staying cyber-safe overseas in the wake of Bali e-visa glitch

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wears a dark suit, smiles, and shakes hands with Li Qiang who is in a black suit

props.synopsis: It will be his fifth meeting with Li Qiang, and his second in only a few months.

title.children: Anthony Albanese will meet Chinese Premier Li Qiang on the sidelines of ASEAN summit

image.altText: Trump greets the crowd as he arrives at a campaign rally.

props.synopsis: The millions of US citizens who live overseas rarely get any attention. In 2024, it's a different story.

title.children: US politicians rarely care about overseas voters. This year is different

image.altText: Profile picture of an Indian man.

props.synopsis: Ratan Tata, the former Tata Group chairman who transformed a staid and sprawling Indian conglomerate into a global powerhouse with a string of high-profile acquisitions, has died at the age of 86.

title.children: Indian business titan Ratan Tata dies at 86

image.altText: An aerial shot of people standing on a roof, surrounded by floodwaters.

props.synopsis: The tiny town of Grantham in the Lockyer Valley was hit twice by devastating floods. Here's why it's still going strong.

title.children: How a tiny town rose from the depths of flood despair and came to be known around the world

image.altText: robbie katter frowning

props.synopsis: Less than a decade after abortion was decriminalised, the debate this time would be about whether to reinstate it as a criminal offence, writes Matt Eaton.

title.children: Did a minor Queensland party just make abortion an election issue?

image.altText: Tourists on a desert landscape watch the sunset

props.synopsis: Giving visitors a better understanding of Aboriginal culture is becoming big business in New South Wales, with more than $3 billion spent on cultural tourism in the state last financial year.

title.children: Indigenous tourism experiences raking in billions in NSW alone amid thirst for cultural knowledge

image.altText: An animated concept design showing a football stadium, from above.

props.synopsis: Devonport City Council says a proposed $60 million multi-sport precinct will be a "game changer" for the city, despite some local opposition. Public consultation for the project closes at the end of the week.

title.children: You've heard a lot about a Tasmanian stadium, but this one is not planned for Hobart

image.altText: New Zealand flag in front of civic buildings

props.synopsis: As Australians await stronger signals that a rates reprieve is imminent here, across the Tasman, New Zealand's central bank has again taken the knife to its key interest rate.

title.children: New Zealand 'doubles down' on interest rates retreat with more aggressive cut

image.altText: A family at Uluru

props.synopsis: The Clausens are one of many Australian families hitting the road and homeschooling their kids along the way. They're part of a growing trend of families moving away from mainstream education.

title.children: Ali and Aaron are 'travel schooling' their son. They say he's learning more outside the classroom
